Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Hip Resurfacing and Large-Head Total Hip Arthroplasty in Young and Active Patients with Hip Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: This double-blind, randomised controlled trial was conducted at a single orthopedic center.

Participants.evidence: Forty-eight patients with hip osteoarthritis, selected based on age and activity level, were randomised to receive either HR or large-head THA.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either HR or large-head THA.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the functional outcomes of HR versus large-diameter femoral head THA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was gait speed, assessed preoperatively and at 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty-eight patients were randomised: 24 to HR and 24 to large-head THA.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All participants were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The effect size for gait speed was not significantly different between HR and large-head THA (mean difference = X, 95% CI Y to Z; p = 0.XX).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.
